html:
3.4.20  1:42 am   3.3.20  3:30 am hey bill, thanks for answering.see i'm in my second year of college, and obviously that's not a place where you want to be lazy, but i have managed to just slip by in grades with some luck and the help of classmates. the point is; i always end up doing things at the last moment, were it be studying for a test or doing homework, i always do them at the last day, at the last hour, but somehow, i have managed to survive, just survive. and now the thing is i don't want to keep doing that, i don't want to be so lazy.

      i have lots of free days and spare time and i know i should use that free time studying or doing my homework, but i just don't want to do either of them, because doing something i don't want to just makes me feel awful, almost miserable, like i'm being forced into doing something i hate.

     but at the same time i know i should not feel that way and i should be more responsible .

      sorry for the long answer, but short answer to your question, what i want to do if i weren't so lazy is study and do my homework in my free time instead of doing nothing.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=202003030330

html:
3.2.20  11:30 am   2.29.20  9:26 am
Yes, I can clearly tell if I hit the right ones (like when I learn a song, I know what the 'right' notes are, I can tell without doubt if I'm doing it right, but have completely know sense of the interval relationships between them) after I like try every note around the previous one...and this persists even to now...
I know I'm far ahead on paper and I know I need my ears to catch up, but i really have little idea how I could achieve this.

     (the same thing happens when I try to learn a foreign language. I can read competently in my target language but with toddler level's understanding of audio messages. so it really blows my mind when I heard someone who learnt foreign languages primarily by listening or there are some amazing creatures called illiterate who can speak a language fluently without understanding its orthography). I've been clueless for really long time, and wh en I sea rch online I can only see people who got a great ear but have problem reading staff or sth, none of them in the opposite situation. The things I think I can do now is just doing some mechanical ear training exercise i.e. recognize intervals, chords in isolation one by one, or listening for the melody/chords of songs (mentioned in the previous question) in a fruitless and excruciatingly slow way and wonder along whether I practice the right way... any advice on what I should do? (train in alternative ways or do the same thing with some change)


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=202002290926

2.29.20  9:26 am   i'm a beginner and when i try to figure out the melody or chords of the songs, since i really got no sense of intervals (can only identify them in real slow and artificial situations), it feels like all i can do is hit aimlessly on my keyboard hoping to get the right one. will it make sense one day if i keep at it?

     i think so, but that's just a hypothesis. whenever i went through that stage i was too young to remember so i'm not sure exactly

      it doesnt seem like i'm training my ear since i'm just guessing around hitting keys.

     i guess my first question is, can you tell when you get it right. can you at least hear when you've matched the note. that must be the gateway to all else

      but i know no other ways of training that would serve as the transition from artificial exercises in eartraining programmes to real songs. or are there really other better training ways? i feel like stuck in this.
now i can read the staff and sort of manage to play along with it, and sort of know some theory on paper, but all this seems very far away from real songs or from using my ear ...

     it sounds to me like you are too far ahead on paper. your ear needs to catch up. that's what it seems like to me

2.19.20  4:29 pm   i just realized something amazing! if i play some sort of simple/normal chord progression for a song it allows me to go wild in the bridge because people want something fresh and exciting after hearing the typical chords for so long. i can't believe what i have been missing all these years

     yes, that is true. someone once said to me, 'you know, what i like to do is make sure the verse is not that good, that way the chorus will seem great.' and i kind of thought that was a stupid idea when he said it, but it's nearly impossible to deny the truth of this concept


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=202001121136

1.12.20  11:36 am   Do you think songs need to follow a certain structure (with the verse, chorus, bridge, etc) to be accepted by a mainstream audience?

     absolutely not. in fact, thinking that way will almost certainly lead you astray


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201912050503

12.5.19  5:03 am   alright, so, i got this song idea that im struggling with. the intro, just basically slow moody noodling on piano, is fine. then it moves into a syncopated staccato feel in D minor and i want to find a section to bridge between that and a less-momentum-y chorus-esque section, still in D minor. I also am trying to write lyrics for the whole song (on the subject of loneliness and isolation coz thats the concept of the album) and am struggling with that too. do you have any advice for overcoming my musical and poetic writers block or any avenues i could explore that i havent already?

     although i know the meaning of all the terms you used, still the funny thing about music is there is still no way for me to actually have any idea how your song actually goes. what i might dare to recommend, and i recommend this all too often because it has worked very well for me, is try to write much shorter songs so you can more quickly learn the possibilities. even just the amount of time you've spent giving a verbal description of the song, is enough time to lose momentum of the process. need to go much quicker, more carefree. and for now try shorter songs so you can explore the entire process faster and get more of an idea of what the possibilities can be. and beware that trying to explain a song to someone who hasn't heard it, very often kills it


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201904141116

4.14.19  11:16 am   when i'm writing music i find it difficult to know what kind of section I just wrote (verse, chorus, bridge for example).

     keep an open mind. those terms can fool you, and the only thing that really matters is what happens and when

      However, when i listen to a song, i can easily hear which section is which and what would make sense to come next. Do you have any advice for me?

     apply that strategy to your own songs

embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201801222239

1.22.18  10:39 pm   Hey bill, i really struggle writing bridges to my songs. All the transitions I make seem either way too boring or too out of place, any advice?

     go back to the last point where everything still works. that is called the 'split point.' keep considering every different kind of possibility for what happens after the split point. some ideas you may not have considered: ending the song. repeating something. doing something entirely new. one of these options, people often forget. another interesting trick after the 2nd chorus is launching into the next thing slightly earlier than the end of the 2nd chorus. keep returning to the absolute split point (that's the point before which you are sure everything is totally good) and just keep trying things and be open to anything including ending it. and do timed run-throughs, and to clear your mind each time first, go touch the door handle while the metronome is running and return to the writing station and do the run-through


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201710291233

10.29.17  12:33 pm   i have a song in waltz, around 70 bpm or so, and my verses and chorus are Am, E7 consecutively, i want to write a good bridge for that but i cant come up with a strong chord and i dont really want to use a usual weak one, any progression ideas?

     how about taking the entire song into consideration, as a whole. including the melody and lyrical contents, all together


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201708012218

8.1.17  10:18 pm   I saw a Paul Simon interview online where he was talking about the song Still Crazy After All These Years (unfinished at the time of the interview)... and he said something that I thought was very interesting. He said he wanted to go to either a C or C# in the bridge because he hadn't used them in the melody of the verse. His quote was that "the listener will not ever consciously  say 'those are two new notes I haven't heard". But, in fact, it will be refreshing to the ear." He also compared the same thing to comedy, saying that you can establish a comedic pattern, but then once the pattern is recognized you have to alter it. Just curious what your thoughts are on this?

     i agree fully

      Do you think you do something kind of similar to this in writing songs or making videos?

     yes, making and breaking patterns is something i have mentioned quite a few times here before

12.4.18  11:07 pm   How do you keep your songs so consistently fresh and catchy, despite many of them having very similar overall structures (two verses, bridge, final softer verse)?

     that form doesn't seem entirely familiar, but i just try to have a good time

9.18.18  8:44 pm   any rhyme or reason on which key u go to for a bridge,

     imagination

     or why you like changing keys so much?

     could be fun

      your slidy shifts between keys are distinctive

8.22.18  6:00 am   should I write this bridge in 5/8?

     try it and then run through the entire song from the beginning and see if it makes you excited or disappointed

1.22.18  10:39 pm   Hey bill, i really struggle writing bridges to my songs. All the transitions I make seem either way too boring or too out of place, any advice?

     go back to the last point where everything still works. that is called the 'split point.' keep considering every different kind of possibility for what happens after the split point. some ideas you may not have considered: ending the song. repeating something. doing something entirely new. one of these options, people often forget. another interesting trick after the 2nd chorus is launching into the next thing slightly earlier than the end of the 2nd chorus. keep returning to the absolute split point (that's the point before which you are sure everything is totally good) and just keep trying things and be open to anything including ending it. and do timed run-throughs, and to clear your mind each time first, go touch the door handle while the metronome is running and return to the writing station and do the run-through

10.29.17  12:33 pm   i have a song in waltz, around 70 bpm or so, and my verses and chorus are Am, E7 consecutively, i want to write a good bridge for that but i cant come up with a strong chord and i dont really want to use a usual weak one, any progression ideas?

     how about taking the entire song into consideration, as a whole. including the melody and lyrical contents, all together

8.1.17  10:18 pm   I saw a Paul Simon interview online where he was talking about the song Still Crazy After All These Years (unfinished at the time of the interview)... and he said something that I thought was very interesting. He said he wanted to go to either a C or C# in the bridge because he hadn't used them in the melody of the verse. His quote was that "the listener will not ever consciously  say 'those are two new notes I haven't heard". But, in fact, it will be refreshing to the ear." He also compared the same thing to comedy, saying that you can establish a comedic pattern, but then once the pattern is recognized you have to alter it. Just curious what your thoughts are on this?

     i agree fully

      Do you think you do something kind of similar to this in writing songs or making videos?

     yes, making and breaking patterns is something i have mentioned quite a few times here before

html:
1.28.20  6:13 pm   6.7.19 3:22 pm is there perhaps a similar principle for visuals within videos (such as those you create)?

      i did not plan on saying this here, but i sometimes become extra idealistic when trying to make content like that, and then i realize i have no exact idea of how it can be done, which can also be discouraging.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201906071522

6.7.19  3:22 pm   I am always discouraged by the mixing aspect of music production and not being able to achieve the sound i want. what do i do?

     remember the rock n roll principle (this has nothing to do with rock n roll) you can always imagine a time period where it is technologically impossible to get any sound better than the sound you're getting, and you must find a way to use songwriting the make up for it. there is rock n roll in every time period so just pretend that your sound as it is is all that's available in that time period
original_html:
1.28.20  6:13 pm   6.7.19 3:22 pm is there perhaps a similar principle for visuals within videos (such as those you create)?

      i did not plan on saying this here, but i sometimes become extra idealistic when trying to make content like that, and then i realize i have no exact idea of how it can be done, which can also be discouraging.

answers_original.html:
6.7.19  3:22 pm   I am always discouraged by the mixing aspect of music production and not being able to achieve the sound i want. what do i do?

     remember the rock n roll principle (this has nothing to do with rock n roll) you can always imagine a time period where it is technologically impossible to get any sound better than the sound you're getting, and you must find a way to use songwriting the make up for it. there is rock n roll in every time period so just pretend that your sound as it is is all that's available in that time period

     probably a rectangular prism that changes color

      and how do you create it?

      probably make a cube, scale it on 1 axis, maybe keyframe it at 2 slightly different sizes (and rotational positions) over time, then if you can't figure out how to keyframe color changes, you could export 2 different renders, one of each color, and then bring it into a regular video editing/compositing program and then stack the 2 clips, make a vertical cut down both, delete the first half of the first clip and the second half of the second clip, then put them on the same track and crossfade them
original_html:
1.26.20  3:09 pm   Could you post a recipe for ice butter when you return?  Or right now.  Whenever.  No rush.

sure

11.20.19  2:15 pm   What is Ice Butter

     probably a rectangular prism that changes color

      and how do you create it?

      probably make a cube, scale it on 1 axis, maybe keyframe it at 2 slightly different sizes (and rotational positions) over time, then if you can't figure out how to keyframe color changes, you could export 2 different renders, one of each color, and then bring it into a regular video editing/compositing program and then stack the 2 clips, make a vertical cut down both, delete the first half of the first clip and the second half of the second clip, then put them on the same track and crossfade them
